p.s: Out of his conclusion and other excerpts from the play arises the question wetherwhether The Merchant of Venice fuels anti-semitic stereotypes or raises awareness.
On one hand one can argue that it does nothing but fuel anti-semitic stereotypes since Shylock is presented as a money loving antagonist.
He is supposed to be a villanvillain and the viewer shipviewership back then, who only had a generalised idea of a Jewish person, would have only felt empowered in his anti-semiticbelievesbeliefs.
The play is also written in an anti-semitic way since Shylock is only ever described as the Jew which compromises him only to his religion.
He also works with money, another Jewish stereotype.
All of this seems to fuel the anti-semitic stereotype but on the other hand one can see the exact same arguments and argue that all of that is supposed to bring awareness.
The way Shylock is treated by everyone shows the viewer how hard it was to be a Jewish person living in that time period.
As well as the speech Shylock holds about just being a human just like a Christian underlines this argument.
It is written in such a convincing and astonishing way that I would argue ShakespearShakespeare was practically yelling into the viewers' faces Stop being anti-semitic, we are all humans.
After all I am convinced that Shakespeare meant to bring awareness to this problem but might have failed in the execution and the clarity of his stand pointstandpoint.
I also could imagine that he had to hid his stand pointstandpoint in the play in fear of being hated or censored.
